title: Apple Legal Battle Intensifies as Company Fights Judge's Contempt Order
summary: The legal battle - started by Epic Games - could determine the future of the highly lucrative App Store.
full_text_content:
Apple hits back at US judge's 'extraordinary' contempt order
Apple is asking an appeals court to pause a US district judge's recent ruling in a case which could determine the future of its highly lucrative App Store.
Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers found last week the tech giant wilfully violated an order she had previously made in a case filed by Fortnite-maker Epic Games.
That order - handed down in 2021 - demanded Apple refrain from anti-competitive conduct and pricing and allow outside payment options in the App Store.
Last week she determined Apple was flouting that demand - a finding Apple has now called "extraordinary."
The iPhone maker has alleged in a court filing that her order unlawfully prevents the company from controlling "core aspects of its business operations."
"A federal court cannot force Apple to permanently give away free access to its products and services, including intellectual property," the company's lawyers wrote.
Case origins
Both of Judge Gonzalez Rogers' judgements stem from an antitrust case filed by Epic Games.
In 2020, Epic accused the iPhone-maker of possessing an illegal monopoly with its App Store, which collected commissions of between 15% and 30% on in-app purchases.
The judge rejected Epic's monopoly claims, but found Apple was stopping developers from giving users alternative payment options in violation of California competition rules.
She ordered Apple to make changes that would help developers steer customers to cheaper payment options outside of the Apple ecosystem.
Last year, Epic accused Apple of failing to comply by creating a new set of fees for developers instead.
In a contempt order last week, Judge Gonzalez Rogers found that Apple continued to interfere with competition, saying that internal company documents showed Apple deliberately violated her 2021 injunction.
'Substantial sums'
On Wednesday, Apple requested an appeals court take action, including by lifting a ban that stops it from charging developers fees on purchases made outside the App Store.
The company wrote that such restrictions "will cost Apple substantial sums annually" and are based on conduct that has not been found unlawful.
"Rather, they were imposed to punish Apple for purported non-compliance with an earlier state-law Injunction that is itself invalid," Apple wrote.
Apple did not directly addresses Judge Gonzalez Rogers' stunning rebuke of company executives.
In her most recent order, she said CEO Tim Cook ignored executive Phillip Schiller's urging to have Apple comply with her injunction, and allowed then-Chief Financial Officer Luca Maestri to convince him not to.
"Cook chose poorly," she wrote.
The company documents she reviewed reveal "that Apple knew exactly what it was doing and at every turn chose the most anticompetitive option", she wrote.
Apple said last week it would comply with the court's order while it appeals.

## Apple Legal Battle Intensifies as Company Fights Judge's Contempt Order Apple is pushing back against a US district judge's ruling that found the company in contempt for allegedly violating a 2021 order related to its App Store policies. The tech giant has asked an appeals court to pause the decision, arguing it unlawfully restricts Apple's control over its business operations. The case stems from an antitrust lawsuit filed by Epic Games, creator of Fortnite, which accused Apple of anti-competitive practices. Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers ruled last week that Apple deliberately ignored her earlier injunction requiring the company to allow alternative payment options in the App Store. Apple's legal team called the contempt finding "extraordinary," claiming it forces the company to "give away free access to its products and services." ### Key Developments in the Apple Legal Battle The dispute dates back to 2020 when Epic Games sued Apple, alleging the App Store's 15-30% commission fees constituted an illegal monopoly. While the judge rejected the monopoly claim, she ruled Apple violated California competition laws by blocking developers from directing users to cheaper payment methods outside the App Store. Last week, Judge Gonzalez Rogers accused Apple of continuing to interfere with competition, citing internal documents that showed executives, including CEO Tim Cook, knowingly disregarded her injunction. She stated Cook "chose poorly" by ignoring recommendations to comply. Apple has denied wrongdoing and says it will follow the order while appealing. #### Financial and Strategic Implications Apple argues the restrictions could cost it "substantial sums annually" by preventing fees on external purchases. The company maintains the original injunction was invalid and claims the contempt order unfairly punishes it for conduct not deemed unlawful. Legal experts suggest this case could reshape how Apple and other tech giants operate their app marketplaces. #### Frequently Asked Questions
What triggered Apple's legal battle with Epic Games?

Epic Games sued Apple in 2020, alleging the App Store's fees and restrictions violated antitrust laws by stifling competition.

Why did the judge hold Apple in contempt?

Judge Gonzalez Rogers found Apple deliberately ignored her 2021 order to allow alternative payment options, citing internal documents showing executives knowingly avoided compliance.

What happens next in the Apple legal battle?

Apple is appealing the contempt ruling, seeking to pause enforcement while the case proceeds. The outcome could influence future App Store policies.
